title: Tales of passion - Isabel Allende

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message about feminism?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's outdated and only relevant for privileged women.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's dead and should be replaced with a new term.

options.label: C
options.text: That it's not sexy, but still important and necessary.

options.label: D
options.text: That it's only relevant for women in the Western world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message about women's empowerment?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's not necessary for women to have economic independence.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's only beneficial for the women themselves, not for society.

options.label: C
options.text: That giving women education, work, and control over their own income benefits society.

options.label: D
options.text: That women should only be empowered in certain industries.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message about the existing world order?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's perfect and doesn't need any changes.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's only beneficial for the privileged few.

options.label: C
options.text: That it's a mess and needs fundamental changes.

options.label: D
options.text: That it's only relevant for certain countries.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message about the role of women in positions of power?

options.label: A
options.text: That they're not necessary and can be replaced by men.

options.label: B
options.text: That they're only relevant for certain industries.

options.label: C
options.text: That they're necessary for creating a better world.

options.label: D
options.text: That they're only relevant for women who are already in positions of power.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message about the importance of feminine energy in the management of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's not necessary and can be replaced by masculine energy.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's only relevant for certain industries.

options.label: C
options.text: That it's necessary for creating a better world.

options.label: D
options.text: That it's only relevant for women who are already in positions of power.

title: Conserving our spectacular, vulnerable coral reefs - Joshua Drew

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept called when scientists create a system of protected areas nested together like pearls on a string to balance conservation and human needs?

options.label: A
options.text: Connectivity

options.label: B
options.text: Representation

options.label: C
options.text: Insurance

options.label: D
options.text: Resilience

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main benefits of having a string-of-pearls reserve network?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased economic burden on local communities

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced representation of different marine habitats

options.label: C
options.text: Insurance against events like oil spills or coral bleaching

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced connectivity among parks

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists determine if the parks in a reserve network are connected?

options.label: A
options.text: By looking at the physical distance between the parks

options.label: B
options.text: By analyzing the genetic relationships between fish in each park

options.label: C
options.text: By studying the migration patterns of individual species

options.label: D
options.text: By conducting surveys of local communities

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of having parks in both the east and the west in a reserve network?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the number of species in the network

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the economic burden on local communities

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure that populations of certain species remain healthy

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the representation of different marine habitats

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the lessons that can be applied across the world from the reserve connectivity model in Fiji?

options.label: A
options.text: That a single big park is always the most effective way to conserve coral reefs

options.label: B
options.text: That a string-of-pearls reserve network is always the best way to balance conservation and human needs

options.label: C
options.text: That individual parks can function together to create a greater sum than their whole

options.label: D
options.text: That coral reefs are not worth conserving

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Why is there a "b" in doubt? - Gina Cooke

multiple-choice.question: Why does the word "doubt" have a silent "b" in its spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the "b" sound is pronounced in the word's meaning.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the word "doubt" originated from a French word that had a "b" sound.

options.label: C
options.text: Because scribes who wrote English but also knew Latin reinserted the "b" into the word's spelling.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the word "doubt" has a double "b" in its spelling.

multiple-choice.question: What is the historical significance of the "b" in the word "doubt"?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents a change in the word's pronunciation over time.

options.label: B
options.text: It marks the word's origin from a French word.

options.label: C
options.text: It connects the word to other related words in English.

options.label: D
options.text: It indicates the word's meaning as a noun.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the words "doubt" and "double"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are synonyms with opposite meanings.

options.label: B
options.text: They are related through their history and meaning.

options.label: C
options.text: They are unrelated words with different origins.

options.label: D
options.text: They are homophones with the same pronunciation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the historical meaning of the word "tweogan" in Old English?

options.label: A
options.text: It means to question or hesitate.

options.label: B
options.text: It means to have uncertainty or confusion.

options.label: C
options.text: It means to have two minds or be of two opinions.

options.label: D
options.text: It means to have no opinion or no doubts.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the word "doubt" an important example in understanding English spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it shows how words change pronunciation over time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it demonstrates how words borrow from other languages.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it reveals the historical connections between words and their meanings.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a common word with a simple spelling.

options.label: C

title: How did English evolve? - Kate Gardoqui

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Roman Empire's withdrawal from Britain on the Celts?

options.label: A
options.text: The Celts became more powerful and formed their own kingdoms.

options.label: B
options.text: The Celts were protected from the barbarian Saxon tribes of Northern Europe.

options.label: C
options.text: The Celts were forced to flee to other parts of Europe.

options.label: D
options.text: The Celts were absorbed into the Roman Empire.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the Germanic tribes, the Angles, Saxons, Jutes, and Frisians, after the Roman Empire withdrew from Britain?

options.label: A
options.text: They were forced to live in small villages and were not allowed to form kingdoms.

options.label: B
options.text: They quickly sailed across the water, did away with the Celts, and formed kingdoms in the British Isles.

options.label: C
options.text: They were absorbed into the Roman Empire and became Roman citizens.

options.label: D
options.text: They remained in Northern Europe and did not migrate to Britain.

multiple-choice.question: What language did the Danes speak, and how did it affect the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: Old Norse, which mixed with Old English and resulted in the formation of modern English.

options.label: B
options.text: Old English, which became the dominant language in Britain.

options.label: C
options.text: French, which replaced Old English as the language of the British royalty.

options.label: D
options.text: Latin, which was introduced by the Roman Catholic clergymen.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Norman Conquest on the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: It resulted in the replacement of Old English with Old Norse as the dominant language.

options.label: B
options.text: It introduced many French words into the English language, which are still used today.

options.label: C
options.text: It resulted in the elimination of all Germanic languages from the British Isles.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the English language.

multiple-choice.question: Why do words of French origin often evoke a sense of nobility and authority, while words of Saxon origin evoke a sense of peasantry and real people?

options.text: Because of the sounds and spellings of the words themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the way they are pronounced.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the way they are written.

title: The genius of Mendeleev’s periodic table

multiple-choice.question: What was Dmitri Mendeleev's genius in creating the periodic table?

options.text: He arranged elements with similar properties together.

options.label: C
options.text: He predicted the existence of elements that were unknown at the time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because he knew that it was a highly reactive element.

options.label: C

options.label: D
